awd_titl_txt: Design of Twinning Induced Plasticity (TWIP) Magnesium Alloys
awd_abstract_narration:
Magnesium alloys are the lightest structural metals with densities near 34% lighter than aluminum alloys, and are thus very attractive for automotive and aerospace applications where improved fuel efficiency is urgently needed. However, strengthening magnesium alloys through the conventional alloy design approaches that are effective for aluminum alloys has proved difficult. The ductility of magnesium alloys is also low, which results in poor formability at room temperature. The low strength and ductility have limited the industrial applications of magnesium alloys, and new alloy design and processing strategies are needed to overcome these barriers. This award supports fundamental research for a new scheme for magnesium alloy design that departs from conventional approaches, and has the potential to lead to high-strength, ductile magnesium alloys. Computer simulations and experiments will be combined to identify alloying elements that can lead to high strength and ductility. The outcome of this research will provide guidelines for design of new magnesium alloys, leading to improved fuel efficiency of vehicles and reduced emissions. Educationally, this project provides an opportunity for engineering students to conduct computer simulations and experimental studies for alloy design.

Twinning induced plasticity is very effective in achieving high strength and ductility in steels with high manganese concentrations in which mechanical twinning is strain-induced and contributes to the plastic flow and hardening, resulting in superior mechanical properties. In stark contrast, application of twinning induced plasticity is lacking in magnesium alloys, despite the fact that profuse twinning can be activated, because twinning is stress-induced at low stress levels in these alloys. Thus, to introduce twinning induced plasticity into magnesium alloys, the critical stress for twinning must be increased. In this research project, first principles calculations will be performed to identify alloying elements that have significant influences on the c/a ratio of magnesium alloys and the energy barrier for atomic shuffling during deformation twinning. These parameters control the critical stress for twin nucleation and growth. After these alloying elements are identified, alloy synthesis and thermomechanical processing will be conducted to achieve the optimal mechanical properties. This strategy opens a new window for sustainable design and processing of high performance magnesium alloys without resorting to expensive and exotic alloying elements.

por.por_cntn:
Magnesium (Mg) is a very promising structural material with a density that is 36% lower than that of aluminum (Al). Application of Mg alloys in automotive and aerospace industries would effectively improve fuel efficiency and reduce greenhouse gas emissions. However, a major technical barrier that prevents Mg alloys from broad engineering applications is their relatively poor ductility and formability at room temperature. For instance, sheet rolling or stamping of Mg alloys cannot be performed at room temperature due to cracking and have to be conducted at elevated temperatures, leading to increased energy cost. To improve the mechanical properties of Mg alloys, rare earth elements have been used. This NSF funded project explores the possibility of a new strategy for developing Mg alloys with improved ductility by introducing the effect of twinning induced plasticity (TWIP) into Mg, without using rare earth. TWIP has been successfully utilized in developing the second-generation advanced high strength steels, in which deformation twinning contributes to the high strength and ductility. Profuse twinning can happen during deformation of Mg alloys, however, no TWIP effect has been observed in Mg and alloys.

The hypothesis of this project is that the critical stresses for activating twinning and twin growth in Mg is so low that twinning dominates the low stress stage of deformation, and saturates before dislocation dominated plasticity starts. This leads to essentially little twin-slip interaction. Thus, to have the TWIP effect in Mg, twinning needs to pushed to the high-stress plastic range by choosing proper alloying elements.

This project systematically investigated the twinning mechanism in Mg by performing extensive computer simulations at atomic and electronic scale, as well as experimental studies. It was found that the underlying physics is fundamentally different from what was predicted in classical twinning theory. Complex twin-slip, twin-twin, as well as twin-precipitate interaction were studied and a much better understanding was achieved. These computational and experimental results can be explained well by the non-classical twinning behavior, and the conclusions can be extended to other hexagonal close-packed metals such as Ti, Zr and Co etc.

Effects of most commonly used alloying elements on deformation twinning in Mg was investigated by computational and experimental studies, in order to identify viable processing methods to achieve TWIP effect in Mg alloys and facilitate design of new Mg alloys. Quantum mechanics-based calculations were performed to study interaction between solute atoms and Mg. Such interaction strongly influences twin nucleation and growth in Mg. Figure 1 shows how solute Al atoms in Mg affect the distribution of electron density and thus the bond strength. These calculation results indicate that solute Al atoms enhance the bonding on the basal plane. This behavior can effectively suppress or delay twinning. Figure 2 shows how solute Zn atoms in Mg affect the distribution of electron density. The results indicate that high concentration Zn atoms in solid solution are able to strengthen Mg-Mg and Mg-Zn bonds, leading to increased twinning stresses. The calculation results can be well correlated to the experimental observations, as shown in Figure 3. Al is added to Mg in commercial alloys to achieve precipitation hardening of Mg alloys. However, the experimental result in Figure 3 indicate that, by solution treatment of a commercial, extruded AZ80 Mg alloy with an Al concentration ~8.0%, deformation twinning is significantly suppressed or delayed. These computational and experimental results indicate that it is feasible to design and process cost-effective Mg alloys with improved mechanical properties by controlling deformation twinning.

 


Last Modified: 04/30/2021
Modified by: Bin Li

Images (1 of )
  • (a) Electron localization function (ELF) for pure Mg. (b-c) ELF for Mg-Al alloys. Electrons are more localized around Al atoms on the basal plane. (d-e) Charge density difference for Mg-Al alloys. Solute Al atoms enhance the bonding on the basal plane, thus inhibit twinning.
    Bin Li
    Copyrighted
    Bin Li
    Figure 1
  • Twinning behavior of solutionized commercial, extruded AZ80 Mg alloy in compression along the extrusion direction. The twin volume fraction at a high strain level (6.3%) is significantly reduced, drastically different from the same alloy without solution treatment.
    Bin Li
    Copyrighted
    Bin Li
    Figure 3
  • (a) Charge density distribution for Mg and Mg-Zn alloys. The distribution changes more significantly with increasing at%Zn. (b) Electron localization function (ELF) for Mg and Mg-Zn alloys. For higher Zn%, both Mg-Mg and Mg-Zn bond strength increase, leading to the increase of twinning stresses.
    Bin Li
    Copyrighted
    Bin Li
    Figure 2
por.por_txt_cntn:
Magnesium (Mg) is a very promising structural material with a density that is 36% lower than that of aluminum (Al). Application of Mg alloys in automotive and aerospace industries would effectively improve fuel efficiency and reduce greenhouse gas emissions. However, a major technical barrier that prevents Mg alloys from broad engineering applications is their relatively poor ductility and formability at room temperature. For instance, sheet rolling or stamping of Mg alloys cannot be performed at room temperature due to cracking and have to be conducted at elevated temperatures, leading to increased energy cost. To improve the mechanical properties of Mg alloys, rare earth elements have been used. This NSF funded project explores the possibility of a new strategy for developing Mg alloys with improved ductility by introducing the effect of twinning induced plasticity (TWIP) into Mg, without using rare earth. TWIP has been successfully utilized in developing the second-generation advanced high strength steels, in which deformation twinning contributes to the high strength and ductility. Profuse twinning can happen during deformation of Mg alloys, however, no TWIP effect has been observed in Mg and alloys.

The hypothesis of this project is that the critical stresses for activating twinning and twin growth in Mg is so low that twinning dominates the low stress stage of deformation, and saturates before dislocation dominated plasticity starts. This leads to essentially little twin-slip interaction. Thus, to have the TWIP effect in Mg, twinning needs to pushed to the high-stress plastic range by choosing proper alloying elements.

This project systematically investigated the twinning mechanism in Mg by performing extensive computer simulations at atomic and electronic scale, as well as experimental studies. Effects of most commonly used alloying elements on deformation twinning in Mg was investigated by computational and experimental studies, in order to identify viable processing methods to achieve TWIP effect in Mg alloys and facilitate design of new Mg alloys. Quantum mechanics-based calculations were performed to study interaction between solute atoms and Mg. Such interaction strongly influences twin nucleation and growth in Mg. These calculation results indicate that solute Al atoms enhance the bonding on the basal plane. This behavior can effectively suppress or delay twinning. Figure 2 shows how solute Zn atoms in Mg affect the distribution of electron density. The calculation results can be well correlated to the experimental observations, as shown in Figure 3. Al is added to Mg in commercial alloys to achieve precipitation hardening of Mg alloys. However, the experimental result in Figure 3 indicate that, by solution treatment of a commercial, extruded AZ80 Mg alloy with an Al concentration ~8.0%, deformation twinning is significantly suppressed or delayed. These computational and experimental results indicate that it is feasible to design and process cost-effective Mg alloys with improved mechanical properties by controlling deformation twinning.
